awd_titl_txt: Learning in Places: Field Based Science in Early Childhood Education
awd_abstract_narration:
Recent evidence suggests that reasoning and making decisions about ecological systems is a cultural activity that impacts participation in the core scientific practices of observation, evidence use, and claims making. This project aims to develop an innovative field-based science learning approach that will support the capacity of culturally diverse students in Grades K-3 to engage in complex ecological reasoning and related problem solving. To provide rich learning environments, outdoor learning gardens will be created in which students, teachers, garden educators, and families participate in activities that facilitate the investigation of tangible ecological challenges such as water capture and food security. This project is funded by the Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12, which seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

Using design-based research, the project team will collaborate with teachers, parents of participating students, and community garden educators to collectively design and develop four key components: 1) field-based curricular units for K-3 classrooms; 2) a model of family and community engagement that strengthens cultural relevance and equity in field-based science learning; 3) a pilot program of teacher professional development that informs future scaling efforts; and 4) research that unpacks student learning and teacher instructional practices that support children?s complex ecological reasoning and the cultural contexts of such knowledge. Data sources will include video, interviews, surveys, and student-created artifacts. A mixed-methods approach will be used to produce research findings at multiple levels including: student learning about complex ecological phenomena and field-based practices; classroom-level learning and high-leverage teaching practices in model units at each grade level; impacts of co-design on professional learning and practice; and family and community organizations learning and engagement in field-based science education. The project will be carried out by a research-practice-community partnership in Seattle, Washington that includes learning scientists (University of Washington), K-3 teachers and school administrators (Seattle Public Schools), garden educators (Seattle Tilth), and parents of participating students. In total, eight schools, 32 teachers, 800 students, and 32 families are expected to participate.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit: 

Learning in Places project aimed to co-design innovative research and practice with educators, families, and community partners that cultivates equitable, culturally based, socio-ecological systems learning and sustainable decision-making utilizing “field based” science education in outdoor places, including gardens, for children in pre-Kindergarten to 3rd grade and their families. The project has produced new knowledge around the nature of family discussions in indoor and outdoor settings, student wondering and awe, and family co-design and engagement. In addition, we have at least four areas of impact to report:

  1. Place based design practices: with the design of the outdoor place  co-design guide, this has the potential to impact how CBOs and schools partner with the larger community to co-design outdoor spaces for equity-centered learning. Our frameworks on designing with places  guide educators to consider how to design instruction with place, rather than simply using place as a backdrop or context. 

  2. Storyline development that includes families and communities: One innovation of the Learning in Places storyline model is the routine way in which family and community knowledges and practices are engaged throughout the storyline. This is a model of discipline-specific family engagement that goes far beyond the family engagement models based on compliance or family “cultural nights”. We have developed a typology of family tools that involve families in wondering and noticing, ethical deliberation and decision making, and field-based science practices. Leadership teachers and teachers in our professional development have indicated that this is paradigm-shifting for them and has involved both re-envisioning relationships with families and learning to see family knowledges as sophisticated and rich sources upon which to build their instruction. 

  3. A model of partnership between schools and community organizations: with the design of the outdoor co-design guide, the educator frameworks, and the rhizome, Learning in Places has designed a comprehensive model of how field-based science education can be envisioned from the outset with deep partnership between families, schools, and communities, always holding power and historicity (and relationships) at the core. 

  4. Ethical deliberation and decision-making through “should-we” questions: there has been powerful uptake of our model of “should-we” questions and ethical deliberation and decision making. “Should-we” questions drive field-based investigation cycles that lead to ethical deliberation and decision-making based on evidence.  


Broader impacts: 

Outcomes for this project include: (1) fully designed field-based seasonal storyline materials for use in classrooms, out-of-school, and family settings, along with accompanying student and family tools and teacher educative materials, (2) a model of yearlong professional development to support educators in implementing the seasonal storyline, (3) 33 publications, conference presentations/talks, book chapters, and invited talks, and (4) a website that has been accessed thousands of times from users around the world downloading learning materials. In addition, Learning in Places was funded for a second round of development and study by the National Science Foundation, to expand to grades PreK-5 towards a transdisciplinary model of learning (science with social studies/civics and literacy), and across six states. In addition to these outcomes, Learning in Places has been utilized in preservice teacher education courses across the country and has been featured in a recent report by the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (NASEM), The Brilliance of Children and the Strengths of Educators (NASEM, 2020). 




Last Modified: 01/30/2024
Modified by: Carrie T Tzou
por.por_txt_cntn:
Intellectual merit:


Learning in Places project aimed to co-design innovative research and practice with educators, families, and community partners that cultivates equitable, culturally based, socio-ecological systems learning and sustainable decision-making utilizing field based science education in outdoor places, including gardens, for children in pre-Kindergarten to 3rd grade and their families. The project has produced new knowledge around the nature of family discussions in indoor and outdoor settings, student wondering and awe, and family co-design and engagement. In addition, we have at least four areas of impact to report:




Place based design practices: with the design of the outdoor place co-design guide, this has the potential to impact how CBOs and schools partner with the larger community to co-design outdoor spaces for equity-centered learning. Our frameworks on designing with places guide educators to consider how to design instruction with place, rather than simply using place as a backdrop or context.




Storyline development that includes families and communities: One innovation of the Learning in Places storyline model is the routine way in which family and community knowledges and practices are engaged throughout the storyline. This is a model of discipline-specific family engagement that goes far beyond the family engagement models based on compliance or family cultural nights. We have developed a typology of family tools that involve families in wondering and noticing, ethical deliberation and decision making, and field-based science practices. Leadership teachers and teachers in our professional development have indicated that this is paradigm-shifting for them and has involved both re-envisioning relationships with families and learning to see family knowledges as sophisticated and rich sources upon which to build their instruction.




A model of partnership between schools and community organizations: with the design of the outdoor co-design guide, the educator frameworks, and the rhizome, Learning in Places has designed a comprehensive model of how field-based science education can be envisioned from the outset with deep partnership between families, schools, and communities, always holding power and historicity (and relationships) at the core.




Ethical deliberation and decision-making through should-we questions: there has been powerful uptake of our model of should-we questions and ethical deliberation and decision making. Should-we questions drive field-based investigation cycles that lead to ethical deliberation and decision-making based on evidence.





Broader impacts:


Outcomes for this project include: (1) fully designed field-based seasonal storyline materials for use in classrooms, out-of-school, and family settings, along with accompanying student and family tools and teacher educative materials, (2) a model of yearlong professional development to support educators in implementing the seasonal storyline, (3) 33 publications, conference presentations/talks, book chapters, and invited talks, and (4) a website that has been accessed thousands of times from users around the world downloading learning materials. In addition, Learning in Places was funded for a second round of development and study by the National Science Foundation, to expand to grades PreK-5 towards a transdisciplinary model of learning (science with social studies/civics and literacy), and across six states. In addition to these outcomes, Learning in Places has been utilized in preservice teacher education courses across the country and has been featured in a recent report by the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine (NASEM), The Brilliance of Children and the Strengths of Educators (NASEM, 2020).
